ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to create an extended creative piece.

I worked on developing my fiction writing and short story skills. I was able to focus on the craft of creative writing in a focused and concentrated environment, while reading other examples of short fiction.
With the guidance of my amazing advisor, how to be a better writer.

This project has given me more than any class I have ever taken, and my advisor has taught me more about how to approach and think about writing than anyone else in my life. I have learned how to be more intentional about every word, to think more critically about what the specific language I use conveys, and to develop first drafts into much stronger pieces. Overall, my work just vastly improved -- it is clearer, smarter, more pointed, more meaningful, and overall, just better than it previously has been, thanks to feedback from my advisor, her assistant, and other faculty and students in the Writing Concentration.
I developed the skills to write a longer piece of writing that was closely edited by a seasoned advisor.
I grew enormously as a writer, learning to approach large-scale projects and edit my work to a high level of polish.

This course represented the first time I was able to take on a creative project of this length, and I believe the skills I learned in perseverance, editing, and collaborating with others will be incredibly valuable to me in the future.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: One-on-one interaction with your advisor, so many amazing guest speakers, you learn how to become a better writer
Weaknesses: None
Strengths--all the one-on-one feedback and communication about my writing
This course was solely for improving and working on my writing, so I don't see any real weakness.
I can imagine that the program is really different in person, and feel like everyone did the best they could given the current circumstances.

Strengths: Everything -- it's a thesis in which you get to do creative writing! What is there NOT to love? I would have loved to be more engaged in the broader Writing Concentrators' community than I was, but I feel that is more a function of COVID than course issues.

I think the strengths were definitely just how in-depth you go with one piece of writing, the talks by authors, and hearing the other concentrators' work. Just wish some of it could have been in person.
I like the individual and communal parts of this course. It's great to have your own project, but do it in companionship with other writers. The balance works well.

Strengths: creative liberty, the combination between independent and supervised work

Weaknesses: none

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Virtual meetings with my advisor and the small group meetings with other concentrators was successfully done
I thought the group Zooms and lunches worked as well as virtual events can work!

The virtual meeting with my advisor every week felt pretty normal, even with it being online. The talks and ball would have been better in person, but that wasn't possible due to the public health situation.

My individual meetings with my mentor were wonderful, and the group Concentration meetings worked well too. I was glad we did meetings for each genre. The only thing that didn't go all that well for me was the scheduling of the meetings. Since they were scheduled without input from students, they were often difficult to make. I was really disappointed that I couldn't come to any of the author lunches.
The course operated as well as it could have under the circumstances.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, the writing concentration is great
Yes, for any one interested in creative writing.
Yes.

Yes, absolutely -- nothing else I have done at Yale has meant as much to me as this project does, and I think most Concentrators feel the same way. It is an amazing opportunity to work with brilliant faculty and focus on your writing to an extent that no other course really allows for. It also gives you a chance to see whether a life as a writer is something you're interested in.
Yes I definitely would if you're willing to dedicate a lot of time to working on one creative project.

Yes!! Doing a writing concentration project is such a unique and rewarding experience. It's a lot of work, and largely self-directed, but having a mentor who knows you and your writing well is a wonderful opportunity to grow as a writer and accomplish something that feels really significant.
ABSOLUTELY yes, if you are interested in ever writing a long creative work.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: n/a
N/A
Weekly meetings with my advisor, and group meetings throughout the semester with Professor Zarin and other non-fiction concentrators.

Four-person meetings on a weekly basis with my advisor, her assistant, and the other student working with my advisor; "genre" meetings, in which we met with others completing projects in the same genre; full Concentration lunches and meetings, in which all Concentrators attended (and sometimes advisors)
None
This independent senior course was conducted as a series of personal zoom meetings with my professor.
In combination with meetings with an advisor, meetings as a concentration, and independent work.
